title: Before 1 January 2018, will the European Commission find Google liable in an antitrust case?
preds:
Antitrust: Commission fines Google €2.42 billion for abusing dominance as search engine by giving illegal advantage to own comparison shopping service
http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_IP-17-1784_en.htm
Google reportedly faces record US$1.1bn European Commission fine
ft.com article courtesy of Dbrownian.  Google to be fined this week

It looks like this is going to happen by September: 
https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/16/business/eu-google-antitrust-fine.html I have not looked into the number of cases that are settled via fine without a company being "liable" to see if that might be possible.

When doing my initial research for this question I seem to have missed that the Google Search (Shopping) case was initiated in 2010 and not 2016... oh well better late than never I suppose. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-06-10/google-execs-hunker-down-for-summer-fight-with-eu-as-fines-loom

Significantly increasing my answer because of this Reuters story claiming there will be a resolution to these antitrust cases in the next few months. Certainly sounds like this year, and that Google will be found guilty. http://www.reuters.com/article/us-eu-google-antitrust-idUSKBN18I1EV

It takes about 2 years for a "strong" case to go from "open investigation" to "finding". (Apple case by the same Commission). The investigation is formally open Dec 2016. The 1/6 odd reflects the possibility that the case is expedite due to political pressure, and the much higher average odd given by the respondents to this challenge so far.
Following the people I follow on this one. Haven't paid close enough attention personally.

http://www.nasdaq.com/article/eu-to-resolve-google-antitrust-cases-in-the-next-few-months-cm793420#ixzz4i7s374hS May 23, 2017, 10:41:00 AM EDT By Zacks Equity Research, Zacks.com
. . . 
"A number of technology giants have run into trouble with the [EU] Commission over the years. Microsoft MSFT received a landmark judgment in 2004. More recent targets of the Commission include Amazon AMZN , for e-book deals, Apple AAPL , for its tax practices; and Facebook and Twitter, for hate speech on their platforms. . . ..Google's search technology . . .  gave it a near monopoly advantage. . . .  this dominant position in search has made Google increasingly vulnerable to litigation all over the world, especially in Europe. To make matters worse, Britain decision to exit from the EU comes as a blow. As a result, the company will no longer be able to make use of its more lenient rules on privacy and taxes.  Also, with Britain's exit from the EU, Germany and France, the two countries that have proved particularly difficult for Google, will assume greater influence. So operating in Europe will get tougher before it gets better. " . . .  The company so far has had extraordinary success in the courtroom and with government officials around the world. 
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  The vigor with which the EU has pursued other tech giants and reports of  3 failed attempts at arriving at a settlement suggest to me that Google's success in the courtroom may have ended.
My Dear Google, they got ya!

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-eu-google-antitrust-idUSKBN18I1EV "EU antitrust regulators will rule in the "next few months" whether Alphabet's Google abused its dominance of internet searches and other areas . . . . 
"It made three unsuccessful attempts to settle the internet search case without any finding of wrongdoing and sanctions with European Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager's predecessor, Joaquin Almunia.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  I see several components to this question:
-the closing date. . . .it appears that there will be a ruling in advance of the closing date.
-the decision must be against Google--I'm guessing that the EU has been unwilling to settle with Google because it thinks it has a stong case against it  
-there are 3 cases; this question asks "in an antitrust case", so a decision against Google in any one of the 3 would satisfy the question.

"OXFORD, England (Reuters) - EU antitrust regulators will rule in the "next few months" whether Alphabet's Google abused its dominance of internet searches and other areas, a senior European Commission official said on Monday, an outcome that could lead to a hefty fine." http://ca.reuters.com/article/technologyNews/idCAKBN18I1EV-OCATC
One person does not decide this
Correction for past low rating, based on https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/504231
Should do but deep pockets to be an army of lawyers

I dont think, they'll be so fast. The case is very complicated and i believe, that they will merge the three cases in some way. That will take some time. Generally, there will be a settlement. The case is too complicated. google also won a case in Germany recently.

"As the EU’s Antitrust Chief, Margrethe Vestager, is expected to finalize the first of her three antitrust cases against Google’s abuses of dominance in June-July,..."
http://precursorblog.com/?q=content/google-takeaways-trump-antitrust-chief’s-senate-confirmation-hearing "Her ruling is expected in the coming months and she appears unlikely to stay her hand."
https://www.wired.co.uk/article/margrethe-vestager-apple-facebook-google-antitrust-case

EC has raised antitrust cases against Microsoft, Intel, and Rabmus from 2007 to today.
According to NY Times, battles between Google and EC has been going on for 6 years (2011)
Many EC officials are vocally critical of Google.

https://europeansting.com/2017/05/10/eu-and-amazon-cut-deal-to-end-antitrust-investigation-over-e-books-deals/ Last week the European Commission communicated its decision to formally accept commitments by . . . Amazon to end an EU antitrust investigation over contracts with e-book publishers.  Amazon has proposed to drop some clauses in its contracts that required publishers to inform about terms offered to the company’s competitors and to give to Amazon equal or better terms. . . .  this not the first time EU regulators seek compromises with business giants. The European Commission opened a formal antitrust investigation against Amazon in June 2015. The concern was that, thanks to such “parity clauses”, Amazon may have abused its dominant position on the markets for the retail distribution of English and German language e-books to consumers.  The clauses covered not only price but many aspects that a competitor can use to differentiate itself from Amazon, such as an alternative business (distribution) model, an innovative e-book or a promotion. Article 102 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) and Article 54 of the EEA Agreement prohibit the abuse of a “dominant position which may affect trade and prevent or restrict competition”.
. . . 
Amazon is not the only one tech company to have come under the lens of European regulators in the last few years. Microsoft, Facebook, Intel and, more remarkably, Google all have faced – or are facing – accusations of anti-competitive practices in the 28-country bloc. Also, this is not the first case where the EU’s executive arm accepts or at least takes into consideration an offer by the accused party to settle an antitrust case. Last November, the EU-Gazprom case became prominent after the state-controlled Russian energy group announced it will work on a compromise with EU regulators to finalise a deal to end a five-year antitrust case. It seems that now seeking an agreement with the accused party is becoming a sort of more favourable option not just for the company itself but also for the Commission. Indeed if it is true that no fine could be imposed on a company after the agreement, it is also true that a settlement represents a way to end very complex antitrust cases that otherwise could drag on for years, with a potential negative impact on future investments. Article 9 of the EU’s Antitrust Regulation (Regulation 1/2003) allows the Commission to conclude antitrust proceedings by accepting commitments offered by a company. Such a decision does not reach a conclusion on whether EU antitrust rules have been infringed but legally binds the company to respect the commitments.

The cases under review seem fairly benign. Unless Europe is under political or economic threat as a result of Google, I think this is unlikely. Google and the Tech industry in the United States is capitalistic, but from a political perspective, Google and other tech giants in the US should seem favorable to Europe's democracy in terms of promoting transparency.
Inofficially, fore sure. Even on public-possibly.

The EU will back off going after US industrial champions, as this is in conflict with Trump's America First orientation. The EU needs Trump to move closer to the old orthodoxies of the US being the unequivocal supporter of EU and NATO.
Vestager of the EU's competition commission seems to be serious about going after Google.
Some nice info on the technicalities of the 'Search Engine' case: "Foundem: Remedies in the Google Search Case" http://www.foundem.co.uk/Foundem_Google_Search_Remedies_March_2017.pdf

Drastic change because of this quote from Bloomberg:
"Google is the highest-profile probe facing Vestager, who’s called 2017 her "G year" as she aims to conclude this case as well as a politically charged investigation into Russian gas supplier Gazprom."
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-03-24/eu-said-to-search-for-google-solution-that-stands-test-of-time Vestager is EU Competition Commissioner. I could not find a separate source to confirm the quote.  Assuming the quote is accurate I still leave 10% chance because even a motivated politician with a bit of power and lofty goals deserves 6-8 weeks of holidays come summer in Europe.
Timeline Seems fairly quick for a judgement.
Google are under pressure to play fair and the EU moves slowly. If they are talking they'll both want to avoid an antitrust case to resolve this

I lean a little toward yes in this question because the antitrust case for Google's comparison shopping service has now been going on for two years and so 2017 is within the normal range for a case to be wrapped up. Furthermore, the EC sees this case as setting valuable legal principles for net neutrality (see link). As well, considering the range of investigations, I think it's clear the EC believes Google is guilty, if not for this than for something. https://www.forbes.com/sites/washingtonbytes/2017/03/16/7-reasons-why-europes-antitrust-cases-against-google-are-a-big-deal/#33055fa1498f
In the past, it took 4 years to conclude the proceding against Microsoft.

I think that the EU is unlikely to find google liable for two reasons: 1) they may be merely voicing their concerns via a suit because the feel they have no leverage/bargaining power, otherwise, and 2) they may think that finding google liable may result in a functional decrease in access to services, which they want to avoid.
ToC and Fraud suggestions - while not antritrust - suggest speed and heat are moving to EU

Google, Facebook, Twitter must amend ToS for EU users or face fines
Trio given one month to clean up fraud, scams, and make other fixes.
https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2017/03/google-facebook-twitter-must-comply-with-eu-consumer-law/
Time is on Google's side. The complaints are from 2013-2016, but the case is too complex for a speedy conclusion.

INITIAL GUESS: 1 hour investigation: ## Antitrust timings:
- @chigginson: "Antitrust cases... time is about 3.5 years for a decision to happen"
- @DBrownian: "Resolution of IT antitrust cases in the EU has ranged from 1-4 years" ## Beginning:
- WSJ: EC has brought three antitrust cases ... first Google Shopping, the second Android, and the third AdSense.
- Wikipedia: "On April 15, 2015, the European Commission started an official investigation against Google"
- The proceedings in the latter Google case were opened in July 2016 ## In favor
- Russia has already forced Google to void such terms
- NYT: a final decision in any of the cases is not expected until midway through 2017, at the earliest
- South Korea, Turkey, and India are among the global enforcers who already have commenced their own investigations. ## But
- Forbes: "former Commissioner Joaquin Almunia tried and failed to settle the matter three times."
- United States ... concluded in 2013 that Google did not violate antitrust
- The EU’s antitrust chief ... has said the settlement option is open
- Expert: If it didn’t work under Almunia, my sense is that it wouldn’t work now under Vestager who is really trying to make a point ## RESULTS Timing:
- Naive stimator: 2019, 5, 15
- Gaussian: 24%
- Lognormal: 56%
Total: 40% Liable?
- Previous EU attempts [ - - - ]
- Opened cases [ + + ]
- Previous cases cases [ + - ]
- International pressure [ + ]
- Settlement options [ - ]
- Expert opinion [ - ]
Total: [ + + + + - - - - - - ] ==> 40% FINAL: 16% Feedback is welcome!

Get Google. Someone has to stop the US mass surveillance in its tracks and the only way to do that is to punish Google. “Google has abused its dominant position,” Margrethe Vestager, Europe’s competition chief, said last year when announcing the charges against Google. The company’s “behavior has harmed consumers by restricting innovation in the wider mobile space.” Europe’s OIP files antitrust complaint against Google focused on apps and Google Play
https://techcrunch.com/2017/03/07/europes-oip-files-antitrust-complaint-against-google-focused-on-apps-and-google-play/ In addition to Russia’s cases against Google, South Korea, Turkey, and India are among the global enforcers who already have commenced their own investigations.
https://www.forbes.com/sites/washingtonbytes/2017/03/16/7-reasons-why-europes-antitrust-cases-against-google-are-a-big-deal/#360c63ac1498 Turkey to Investigate Antitrust Complaint Against Google
https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/06/technology/google-turkey-antitrust-android.html

EU consumer authorities to take on Facebook, Google, Twitter
European consumer protection authorities will ask social media companies Facebook, Google and Twitter to amend their terms of service within one month or possibly face fines, a source familiar with the matter said on Thursday. The authorities sent letters to the companies in December telling them that some of their terms of service broke European Union consumer protection law and that they needed to do more to tackle fraud and scams on their websites.
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-socialmedia-eu-consumersconsumers-idUSKBN16N2YI?il=0

Gazprom reaches draft antitrust deal with EU (FT)
Google next?
Initial guess. First article I read WSJ not too informative.

I am sure that the EU will find Google liable with the present legislation, the depth of resolution in this case was technically easy to make based on the data presented by experts. 
Now, the time frame for the resolution is too short for this question to be resolved with a 100% by January 1st. 2018. The EU started the Google case in 2010 and still have to resolve it. They started with opening proceedings in July 2016!
I expect a settlement with the EU opening their tithing bag and collect their 10%.......

Another complaint filed today by a group of internet companies including German newspapers, Axel Springer and a French search engine - various articles on it below. Also mentioned, the Turkish anti-trust investigator are now looking into Google. I think the chances of the EU acting on this are pretty high overt he next year. Frankly with Brexit and elections in France/Germany, I think the Commission may need to justify its existence and this would be a way of the commission protecting its members from the dastardly corporates.
http://www.pcworld.com/article/3177785/android/google-faces-another-antitrust-complaint-in-europe.html
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-eu-google-antitrust-idUSKBN16E1VE
https://www.ft.com/content/03d5b950-05c8-11e4-8b94-00144feab7de

Apple, Google, Amazon and Facebook will be primary targets for their tax evasion and as retaliation against any US trade aggression. There is legislation being prepared to tax US (offshore)  companies in sales geography vs currently at domicile
Unclear strength of case at this time, precedent for cases taking longer for a decision, possibility of other conclusions other than liable in the end.

The link for more info lets you search over cases in the past. 1) Checking out the 55 antitrust cases over the last 10 years and then only paying attention to the first 10 or so ( because the web interface is not very friendly ) it looks like the average time is about 3.5 years for a decision to happen. ( http://ec.europa.eu/competition/elojade/isef/index.cfm?fuseaction=dsp_result ) 2) Paying attention to two big American tech companies that the commission has gone after in the past, Microsoft and Amazon, it looks like Microsoft took 10 years and Amazon 2 years.
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-eu-amazon-com-antitrust-idUSKBN158145 , https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Corp_v_Commission The Google case smells much more like the MSFT case than the AMZN case.  It has the same sort of difficult complexities including non-tech people trying to understand the difference between an api and a browser and what really constitutes a competitor.  Books are much easier. 3) It looks roughly like the Google case started in 2015.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Union_vs._Google I'll assume even distribution from year 3-10 to get ~14%.  Bump down a bit because I think real distribution would have smaller tail in this year.
Going 12%. If over the course of the year the European Commission's web site interface is updated to technology that existed in the year 2000, I may increase the probability.
It takes more time & Google should be able to fight it.
They will find them to be evil as well as all Google accounts (Chrome) and gmail accounts save credit information even if you delete it, Google will find it again. Pure evil. --Craig

I think they will be find liable. There's a confrontational attitude between the Europe and the US, and Europe is particularly weary of US Tech firms. It will happen, will it happen before 1-Jan-2018? Probably not. Google has strong legal prowess and they may be able to delay the whole process for a longer time

The case against Android's dominant position in the app market seems misguided and would set problematic precedents in the IT domain. The case against the presentation of ads in Google search is more credible, and the fact that some differing cases have been merged under this one case would suggest the Commission is putting a fair bit of resources into the investigation. The time it has taken in the past for resolution of IT antitrust cases in the EU has ranged from 1-4 years for companies such as Microsoft (on several occasions) and Intel. The proceedings in the latter Google case were opened in July 2016, hence the earliest we could expect a decision is in Autumn 2017. Given that these cases concern new technology and business models there will  not be many precedents to draw from making the process longer. In addition, Google has sufficient resources to mount a serious legal challenge to the investigation so can draw out the process further. In the end I think it's likely Google will end up having to slightly tweak its ads systems in the EU and pay a fine, but that won't be in 2017.

Europe is very suspicious of dominant US tech companies and I believe that google will be found liable. The main question is when. Google will want to delay as long as possible and there is no legal deadline for the European Commission to conclude this case so it may take a while longer.

Both the US and Europe are finding multinationals to be a good source of revenue beyond the normal tax collection.  Considering the amounts fined the European Banks by the US it will not be surprising to see similar actions against Alphabet, Microsoft and other US multinationals with significant accumulations of earnings outside the US often in Europe.  These types of fines are adjusted so as to maximize the collection without destroying the company.  Such as the US fine to the German bank and as will probably end of being the case with Volkswagen.  If a US tax holiday of say 10% on repatriated earnings by US companies comes into being as is being considered there will be a quick and massive return of this money to be used for dividend payout, loan paydown, stock buy back and maybe even investment in the business.  It will certainly be in part to remove these targeted pools of money from governments sight and reach.
So many cases, but Google's lawyers will delay. Don't expect a quick resolution.
